Jackson wrestles with entrenched notions about recognizing genius and the test of time by comparing the reputations of a dozen writers of the Romantic periodâ€”some famous, some forgotten. Why Keats and not Barry Cornwall, who came from the same circle of writers and had the same mentor? Why not that mentor, Leigh Hunt, himself?
 
Jackson offers new and unorthodox accounts of the coming-to-fame of some of Britainâ€™s most revered authors and compares their reputations and afterlives with those of their contemporary rivals.
